Package ds.graphics

The Graphics package provides tools to display geometric figures and text on a drawing surface.

See:
          Description

Class Summary
CircleShape A derived class the extends Shape with circle objects that are specified by a radius and the base point at the center of the figure.
DrawPanel  
DrawTools This class contains static methods which open, close, and erase the drawing surface as well as methods that control the view of graphical frames.
LineShape A derived class the extends Shape with line objects that are specified by a base point and a second point (x,y) which is referred to as the end point.
PolyShape A derived class the extends Shape with regular polygon objects that are specified by a length and the number of sides with the base point at the center of the figure.
RectShape A derived class the extends Shape with rectangle objects that are specified by a length and a width with the base point at the upper left-hand corner of the figure.
Shape A base class for the graphics hierarchy that specifies a base point (x,y) and the color of each figure.
TextShape A derived class the extends Shape with text objects that are specified by a string and a base point positioned at the start of the text.
 

Package ds.graphics Description

The Graphics package provides tools to display geometric figures and text on a drawing surface. The figures include lines, circles, rectangles, and regular polygons. The package is highly customized to allow for the writing of graphical methods and applications without requiring an understanding of the underlying Java graphical system. The package allows a user to control viewing of the window as discrete frames or as time delayed animation frames.

The drawing window is a 10 x 8 unit screen scaled to the dimension and resolution of the monitor. It has a coordinate system with the point (0,0) in the upper left-hand corner. A point (x,y) on the window is a pair of positive real numbers where x is a horizontal distance in the range from 0.0 to 10.0 and y is a vertical distance in the range from 0.0 to 8.0. The point (5.0,4.0) is the center of the window and (9.9, 7.9) is a point very near the lower right-hand corner

Text in the drawing window is a string. The other objects are geometric figures with familiar defining characteristics. For instance, a rectangle is determined by its length and width and a circle by its radius. Besides their specific attributes, all objects on the drawing window share common properties. Each is positioned on the window relative to a base point and is drawn with a fill color. For instance, the following is a light gray rectangle with base point (x,y) at the upper left-hand corner of the figure.

The graphics package is built around an inheritance hierarchy. Shape is the super class with attributes for the base point and fill-color. The abstract class has methods that access and update the attributes. The derived classes, CircleShape, RectShape, LineShape, PolyShape, and TextShape define the graphical objects. Each concrete class has attributes that describe the figure and methods that access and update the attributes as well as drawing the object on the window.

In the DrawTools class, the static method openWindow() identifies the attributes of the monitor and opens a window with a File menu that enables you to print the contents of the screen. The method closeWindow() shuts down the graphics system and returns you to the runtime window. To control the display of figures on the window, use viewWindow() or delayWindow(secs). The first method halts execution of the program until you press the Enter key. The second method temporarily halts the program for a specified number of seconds and then picks up execution. The method is designed for animation. You can clear the entire window with eraseWindow(). Each object has an erase() method that deletes the one figure and redraws the window with the item removed. The following is an API listing of the methods in DrawTools.

The abstract base class Shape defines the base point and color attributes which are common to each graphics object. The class includes the abstract method draw() which is overridden in each of the concrete derived classes that define graphical object. The base point is a pair of real numbers (x,y) of type double. The access methods getX() and getY() return the x and y value of the point respectively. To update the base point, use the method move(x,y). The object uses the new point when it is next drawn on the window. The Graphics package provides a palette of 16 colors of type int. The following is a list of colors, which are defined as static constants in the Shape class.

     WHITE        BLUE          TEAL       GREEN

     TURQUOISE    DARKGRAY      BROWN      PURPLE

     LIGHTBLUE    LIGHTGRAY     GOLD       RED

     ORANGE       PINK          YELLOW     BLACK

The method getColor() provides access to the current color. You can explicitly update the color using setColor(). Some applications want to cycle through the colors in the palette. To this end, the method nextColor() simply updates the current color to the next one in the palette. After BLACK, the next color is WHITE.

A Graphics Tutorial is provided in the Web supplements. The tutorial gives a detailed description of the drawing surface and the graphics hierarchy which includes the Shape superclass and subclasses for the different figures.
